abstract: The agreement, involving a $73 million payment to the city for a playground, paves the way for waterfront access along the East River. It needs the approval of the U.N., but that is expected.
snippet: The agreement, involving a $73 million payment to the city for a playground, paves the way for waterfront access along the East River. It needs the approval of the U.N., but that is expected.
lead_paragraph: City and state officials on Wednesday agreed to a $73 million plan that would unlock an underutilized chunk of the Manhattan waterfront between East 38th and East 60th Streets, paving the way for a new United Nations office tower and esplanade along the East River.

headline.main: Land Deal Is Announced to Allow New U.N. Tower and Esplanade
